title: ECLECTIC RESONANCE Legendaria
price: Pre-Order & Event Price: 12€ / 2000 yen | Post Release Price: 15€ / 2400 yen

01.title: The Wisp and the Willow Tree
description: • Composer: Philip Saguil (Resonant Union), Emma Kobin
• Programmed, Produced & Mixed by Philip Saguil
• Used VSTs & Samples: Ilya Efimov Nylon Guitar, SWAM Violin, SWAM Cello, Lo-Ki Soft Piano, LABS Music Box

• About this track: I wrote this track over two years ago for Emma. I never ended up releasing it, but when time came for Legendaria to close, I asked Emma if she would write lyrics and sing over it for the submission. She said yes, and turned the instrumental into a gorgeous song!
The flowers, the swords within you
But here alone beneath this tree
There's a storm in my eyes
I stay the same so you can change
In the center of the crowd when
I knew you'd find a way to stay
I looked up at the stars
I knew that they were ours
I knew that just as the sand
Your soul will break down their
Walls just to return home to me
In the woods, in the meadow,
I'll wait for you, as I have before

02.title: A Mysterious Prophecy
description: • Used VSTs & Samples: Embertone - Joshua Bell Violin (solo violin); Spectrasonics - Trilian (synth bass); Roland JV-1080 + SRX Orchestra (all the rest)

• About this track: This track focuses on the softer and meditative side of old school JRPG music.  It is one of my belief that JRPGs soundtracks did a lot of good for classical music. The extent of the influence of classical music in those kind of music is non-negligible and, as a result, an extraordinary amount of JRPGs got symphonic arrangements albums and concerts. A lot of those concerts, despite being held in usually classical venues, are often sold-out. Most of the people attending are young and not the kind to be classical concertgoers. The main instruments of this track are the violin and piano, two staples of western classical music, whether it is in chamber music or pieces written for large ensembles. The other instruments and sounds are almost all from an old rompler featured prominently in 90's RPGs, with most of these aforementioned RPGs seeing symphonic arrangements later down the line.

03.title: Adventure of a Day
description: • Piano, Whistle & Soprano Saxophone: Justin Thornburgh (Resonant Union)
• Programmed, Produced & Mixed by Justin Thornburgh (Resonant Union)
• Used VSTs & Samples: Spitfire Chamber Strings, Spitfire Studio Brass, EW Hollywood Orchestral Percussion

• About this track: Celebrating the day-to-day, this track paints the possibilities of the adventure that is living each day with joy and passion. Inspired by the slice of live genre and the Atelier soundtracks.

04.title: Blossom Magic
description: • Programmed, Produced & Mixed by Tamari (Welkin Strider)
• Used VSTs & Samples: Celtic Era 2, Indian Bells
• About this track: The travelers are resting at the side of a river. They enjoy listening to a singing bird and feel the breeze. With her spell, the girl blooms flowers around them.

05.title: Grasslands
description: • Used VSTs & Samples: Orange Tree Samples - Evolution Steel Strings (guitar); Musical Sampling - Hoard Fingerstyle (guitar); Impact Soundworks - Pearl Concert Grand (piano); Best Service - Celtic ERA 2 (tin whistle); Strezov Sampling - Balkan Ethnic Orchestra (choir); Native Instruments - Kontakt Factory Library (celesta); Spitfire Audio - Spitfire Chamber Strings (strings ensemble); Loops de la Crème - Clap Pack Deluxe 2 (hand claps); GForce Software - M-Tron Pro IV (mellotron flutes); Spectrasonics - Trilian (fretless bass)

• About this track: This is a track heavily inspired by world music seen through the lens of various JRPGs such as the Suikoden or Atelier series. The title itself is a reference to a track from Chrono Cross often known as "The Grasslands of Time: Home World", and the influence of Yasunori Mitsuda is overall quite obvious. Other than that, I also took inspiration from various folk music, especially Spanish ones. The harmonies and melodies also shows some influences from a Japanese band named Choro Club, who themselves are primarily influenced by diverse folk music. Those are all pretty natural influences and inspirations of mine, so this track is kind of a candid love letter to them.

06.title: Du Rififi dans la Ville Fleurie
description: • Acoustic Guitar, Bass Guitar, Flute, Melodica, Djembe, Salt Shaker, Tambourine, Bongos, Claps: Tee-vee
• Used VSTs & Samples: Kontakt 7, NI Sessions Strings Pro 2, Korg Triton Extreme, Korg M1, Korg MonoPoly, Arturia B-3V, Arturia Mellotron V, NI Mallet Flux, NI Noire

• About this track: Experimented a whole bunch with my acoustic instruments for this one, also particularly happy with the "chorus" melody considering how fast it came to be. Can you tell I'm still very new to flute. The section around 2:15 is the rififi part, the rest is Ville Fleurie

07.title: LUNATIC DRIVE
description: • Mastering Engineer: malicent (Cursed Monastery / Sigillum Azoetia)
• Used VSTs & Samples: classic Roland drum machines, Ryu Umemoto FM slap bass and brass patches, Korg M1 e. piano, lead gtr ptvoice from Nyll_Fomid's pxtoneKit, other ptvoices from pepofont

• About this track: I have always thought this chord progression was really striking and unusual, so I had to jump at this opportunity to do something with it even though I was pretty busy at the time. It's a little bit hacky, but please enjoy! I put a lot of my favorite sounds in it. I'm starting to think this style is a little different from what usually goes on these albums...

08.title: Battboy Slim Jr. (Fucking In Santa Destroy)
description: • Original Composer: Tomohiro Shirai & Kazuhiro Goto
• Mastering Engineer: malicent (Cursed Monastery / Sigillum Azoetia)
• Source: No More Heroes 2: Desperate Struggle
• Used VSTs & Samples: Surf Santa Destroy and Ms. Teller drum loops, No More Heroes 2 cutscene voicelines + one Travis Strikes Again voiceline

• About this track: No More Heroes 2 is one of the best soundtracks and one of the best games I have ever experienced, which forced my hand to arrange from it (but I mean that in a good way). After working on a failed remix of another song from the game, I decided to remix Travesty instead, after relistening and realising it had perfect big beat riff energy, like the kind of thing you'd hear in a Tekken 3 song, so I went all in with the idea. Watch out for Jasper Batt Jr's new Big Batt album, The Batt of The Land. In stores never. [some sort of joke about Pizza Bat and the alias Pizzaman goes here]

09.title: Heroic Verse (Tobokegao Y2K VGM Vibes Remix)
description: • Programmed, Produced, Mixed & Mastered by Tobokegao

10.title: Ohma Gawd
description: • Programmed, Produced, Mixed & Mastered by Nuchuu

• About this track: This track focuses on the absurd nature of Ohma and the environment Ohma is fought in, taking melodic motifs from the theme and placing them into a high-energy, progressive psytrance inspired journey.

11.title: Apricot Jam for Dissociative Squares
description: • Programmed, Produced & Mixed by Hal Binderman
• Mastering Engineer: malicent (Cursed Monastery / Sigillum Azoetia)
• Used VSTs & Samples: plogue Chipspeech, Reason Drum Kits, Reason Electric Bass, Radical Keys, Malstrom

• About this track: Early Grasshopper games have a strong presence in my mind, especially when it comes to music. Takada-san's composition always stood out, and it has a consistency throughout his time with Grasshopper that gives their games of that era a strong character. "killer7" was my first Grasshopper game, and it made an extremely strong impact on me. I played "The Silver Case" later, and it affected me in different ways. While thinking about the project, I wondered if there was a way I could represent both titles in one track? For a while, I've thought that "Apricot Square" and "Dissociative Identity" both have strong piano melodies that could complement each other well, so I began with them. In fact, several elements of each track - melodies, chords, instruments - seemed to work together famously. I didn't have to make many alterations at all, just enough to keep things in key. I wrote a new bass line based on the roots of "DI", and introduced a second lead in the background to make the piece more my own. I think it still leans more towards "DI" than "AS" overall, likely because the former is a more developed idea in my opinion. I hope you enjoy it! I look forward to ever more unique experiences from Grasshopper. ^^
